Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Instance Segmentation in Support of Sustainable Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable production of high resolution, timely, affordable data on agricultural productivity and economic outcomes across Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), where access to demographic and market data is severely limited. The project proposes a set of machine learning methods for extracting objects, like farm fields and housing, from earth observation datasets. There are three key impacts enabled by the proposed technology. First, there are open scientific questions related to the efficient detection of objects in satellite imagery, particularly in rural developing country contexts, where training data are sparse. Second, the project is expected to significantly improve the accuracy of existing models for the prediction of socio-economic outcomes, by generating valuable new model inputs and improving the handling of missing data. Third, it seeks to expand the universe of socio-economic information that can be extracted from satellite imagery, by enabling the prediction of outcomes that previously have not been feasible. The resulting market intelligence products will revolutionize the cost effectiveness of agribusinesses, non-governmental organizations, and governments operating in SSA, enabling them to enter and serve fast-growing consumer markets across the continent.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on developing computationally efficient methods for segmenting images with rich geospatial content. It evaluates a series of deep learning architectures that extract relevant objects from composites of different earth observation datasets. A key technical challenge is designing models that make effective use of satellite imagery that spans multiple spatial resolutions, temporal frequencies, and sensing modalities. This presents unique opportunities and challenges compared to mainstream research on weakly supervised learning in traditional computer vision applications. The project's objectives are to 1) develop and test instance segmentation techniques that leverage the unique spatiotemporal information available in different types of earth observation data; and 2) innovate new learning approaches for handling missing inputs and dealing with sparse training data. Algorithms developed by this project will be evaluated using standard metrics for model performance, leveraging existing household survey data for testing and validation. Downstream benefits of the project include lower-cost access to market intelligence that can unlock underserved markets, expansion of the set of economic indicators that can be derived from earth observation data, and improved targeting of development assistance to people living in emerging economies, enabling cost-efficiencies for donors like USAID.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In most developing countries, the agriculture sector operates without access to timely data on productivity, distribution, and pricing. Better agricultural data could drive rapid productivity growth in regions like Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), where most farmers cultivate fewer than two hectares of land (FAO). These small family farms are under pressure to intensify production over the next decade, to meet the needs of a quickly expanding population. Yet African farmers? crops are rainfed, and their landholdings are modest. As a result, they need specialized financial services ? including low-cost crop insurance to weather yield loss, and credit to invest in growth. The problem is that financial service providers have found it challenging to succeed in African agricultural markets in the absence of reliable agricultural statistics. As a result, most organizations financing small farms are subsidized by philanthropists and impact investors, which is not sustainable.

Atlas AI has been addressing these issues by generating historical post-season yield estimates with a resolution of 10 m/px in several SSA countries. We entered the Phase-1 SBIR program with the idea of adding a useful feature to these insights: AI-based automatic detection of field boundaries from satellite imagery. However, interacting with potential customers during the early stages of the program had a transformative effect on our product development plan. Many of the customers we interviewed expressed a strong interest in having an in-season yield forecast product, while the automatic segmentation of field parcels we initially proposed appeared less valuable. With this new information at hand, we decided to pivot our technical research toward the development of yield forecasting models based on satellite observations. We used this first phase of experimentation to de-risk our forecasting technology in two ways.

First, we tested the hypothesis that pixel-level yield forecasts can be a valuable product for financial services providers. We centered this exercise on the index insurance business, i.e., a provision insurance system that pays out benefits based on a predetermined index for yield loss. We analyzed the ability of different indexes currently used by insurance companies to capture temporal and spatial yield variability and compared them with our post-season yield estimates. Our estimates outperformed insurance indexes significantly when measured against ground data for maize yield in Kenya.

Second, we prototyped different models to forecast maize yield in Kenya: three methods based on simpler empirical approaches, and one based on deep learning techniques. All methods used a combination of weather data and satellite observations of vegetation greenness and were trained and tested with ground yield data collected in different regions of Kenya. The models were tasked with generating a regular series of end-of-season yield projections provided throughout the season. The series would start with forecasts based on early observations at planting time and would continue until harvest time. As the season unfolds, more satellite and weather observations become available to the models. All methods generated forecasts with variable performance; test R2 values ranged from 0.20 to 0.78 depending on the time of the season and the model used. The deep learning approach, a sequence-based Deep Neural Networks (DNN), was the best performing model throughout the season.

Our preliminary results show that there is some clear potential for generating a reliable yield forecasting product. Not only this data seem to have very impactful applications in real-life products, but the experiments we ran produced promising results in terms of accuracy and scalability for a variety of models. Every model we tested was able to forecast maize yield at the aggregated level (district and county), although with different performance in each case. A few key issues will have to be resolved before we can turn these efforts into a reliable product. First, the accuracy of the predictions needs to be improved. The performance of the different models tested has shown us that, to some degree, the model type and architecture can contribute to improving accuracy. Second, although useful for some applications, aggregated forecasts do not leverage the full potential of satellite observations and they limit the range of possible applications. Producing yield forecasts with higher granularity would unlock key applications around precision agriculture, insurance, and credit loans. In the next phase of research, we will address these concerns.
